newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.

text.p: The South African rand recovered from an initial weaker move, ending off its weakest levels versus the U.S. dollar after shadowing the dollar/mark during the day.
At 1420 GMT the local unit was priced at 4.6940/70 against the greenback from 4.6815/6845 last on Monday after a morning weakest bid of 4.7020.
"The rand was initially pressured by the firmer dollar but managed to fight back as the dollar/mark retreated from resistance at 1.8380," said a senior trader at a smaller institution.
Exporter flows had also aided the unit, he said, as had rumours of Reserve Bank intervention at the 4.7020/7025 level although this was not confirmed.
Dealers said London players had been in the market mainly as speculators.
The dollar/mark was firmer after the German Bundesbank kept its repo rate at 3.0 percent, a reported slowdown in German M3 numbers but it failed to break 1.84.
Market participants await the outcome of the U.S. Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, which should hit the screens at around 1815 GMT, although it is generally expected to be a non-event.
On future direction, traders said they would continue their watch on the dollar/mark to anticipate the dollar/rand.
"Rand strength will depend on the dollar/mark. It should trade between 4.65 to 4.72 over the next few days," one trader venturing an opinion said.
In cross rate action, the rand was last priced at 0.3907/3910 on the German mark from 0.3891/3895 late Monday.
Rand/yen was at 25.1505/1879 from 25.1318/1586 and against sterling it was last trading at 7.5418/5514 from 7.5396/5491.
On the fixed income market, bonds wilted towards the end as jobbers sold stock ahead of the outcome of the FOMC meeting.
"It's jobbers playing around that made the market come off but nothing serious," said a trader at a leading bank.
At 1420 GMT the key R150 yielded 14.155 pct from 14.10 pct in late Monday trade.
Bond yields were range-bound during the day as jobbers' attempts to ramp the market higher were countered by institutional buying.
"It's been generally steady. We're basically sitting in there, waiting for fresh news on credit, M3 and inflation," commented a trader at a foreign bank.
He said technical factors would probably dominate over the next few days in the absence of local news.
The market was seen moving in a 14.07 to 14.22 percent range.
The benchmark 30-year U.S. Treasury bond was last trading at 6.51 percent yield after settling at a 6.52 percent yield in New York on Monday.
Foreigners bought 399.79 million rands worth of South African bonds on Monday after buying 229.66 million rands worth on Friday, the Bond Exchange said.
Bond Exchange turnover totalled 7.22 billion rand on Monday from 6.24 billion rand on Friday.
On the money market, offered rates for three-month NCDs were steady at between 15.40 to 15.50 percent, while the 90-day BA rate was also unchanged at 14.90 to 14.95 percent.
The South African Reserve Bank said the money market shortage rose to 8.975 billion rand on Monday after easing slightly to 8.555 billion rand on Saturday.
